body: This seems to be solvable by setting the dipsersion model value thresholds tighter.

I think tighter thresholds on the dispersion should be ok and should not affect the accuracy. Right now, the thresholds are as lenient as numerically possible through `np.nextafter(0, np.inf)` and similar statements. I set the thresholds for r to 1e-10 and 1e10. Dispersion values are expected to be somewhere between 1e-2 and 1e2, I think, so this is still lenient. This was done in https://github.com/theislab/batchglm/commit/9110aee74ad80940e3935d1293a88e4c7a145e4c. Ok, @Hoeze?

issue.title: allow constraints for linear models

repository.name: diffxpy
repository.description: Differential expression analysis for single-cell RNA-seq data.

issue.body: Interface constraints in fitting added in batchglm in https://github.com/theislab/batchglm/pull/18 by documentating and adding the constraints matrices in the diffxpy api.

body: I had to make the thresholds even stricter for @LuckyMD's data set to run. Done here https://github.com/theislab/batchglm/commit/03f2083ead920805b9ed2b36a7dc651a29d7bb4a.
I posted this issue to make this all a bit cleaner https://github.com/theislab/diffxpy/issues/58.

ah sorry, did not see that soon enough.
Just lower `sf` instead of adjusting min/max since this allows the bounds to depend on the data type.
In general, this should be sufficient. 

Otherwise, you can replace `min_r = np.nextafter(...) / sf` directly with `min_r = np.nextafter(...) / <value>`.

Also, watch out if you use float32 vs. float64.

True, it's nicer via sf. I did that and added the factor for sf as a global variable so that users can directly set this if there data set is instable. Fixed in https://github.com/theislab/batchglm/commit/9e7e838d54b20a44919e0f3fc12cf88cd718b9d5.

The new thresholds were bad. sf >=10 is too lenient for the variance model to not break but sf = 100 caused the restriction on the mean model to restrict it from fitting the data. We either need absolute thresholds or different thresholds for variance and mean model. I would go with the latter.

@davidsebfischer Could you set up a jupyter notebook containing only the failing gene?
I'd really like to debug the source of these NaN's as it seems like lowering the bounds might only conceals some missing clipping operation.
Yes, this makes sense at this point. I will share with you tonight or tomorrow. Honestly though, I am almost 100% that tf.NB cannot handle large or small dispersion values in some cases.

Thank you very much, this does not hurry :)

If tf.NB is the problem we can swap it with our own implementation like the one in utils.random.NegativeBinomial.
I already wrapped tf.NB with my own NegativeBinomial class to allow for other parameterizations.

We can check it out - essentially the core evaluation of the NB function is just a computation graph though and therefore there is not much you can change, right? Execept of saving some time on reparameterizations.
